articles.headline: China Stocks Extend Loss, Falling 8.3%
articles.snippet: China’s stock markets have tumbled again, worsening one of the biggest sell-offs in years after the government’s move to impose a higher tax on stock trades.
articles.abstract: China’s stock markets have tumbled again, worsening one of the biggest sell-offs in years after the government’s move to impose a higher tax on stock trades.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI, June 4 — China’s stock markets tumbled again on Monday, worsening one of the biggest sell-offs in years after the government’s move last week to impose a higher tax on stock trades.

articles.headline: Ex-Cisco Executive to Lead Joost, Internet TV Provider
articles.snippet: The high-profile Internet start-up Joost has hired Michelangelo Volpi, 40, as its new chief executive.
articles.abstract: The high-profile Internet start-up Joost has hired Michelangelo Volpi, 40, as its new chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michelangelo Volpi spent 5 of his 13 years at Cisco Systems selling networking equipment to the companies like Comcast and Time Warner Cable that bring television into living rooms.

articles.headline: Court Rebuffs F.C.C. on Fines for Indecency
articles.snippet: Officials said the opinion could gut the ability of the commission to regulate any speech on television or radio.
articles.abstract: Officials said the opinion could gut the ability of the commission to regulate any speech on television or radio.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 4 — If President Bush and Vice President Cheney can blurt out vulgar language, then the government cannot punish broadcast television stations for broadcasting the same words in similarly fleeting contexts.

articles.headline: Gadgets for All of You
articles.snippet: Many consumers find they need to own multiple models of the same device for different uses. So much for one size fits all.
articles.abstract: Many consumers find they need to own multiple models of the same device for different uses. So much for one size fits all.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALISON SHEPARD, a marketing associate for a record label in Manhattan, straps an ultrathin iPod Nano onto her arm before she goes for a run. When she returns to her apartment, she takes off the Nano and turns on the bulkier iPod that has replaced her home music system.

articles.headline: Photo Sharing Even the Folks Can Handle
articles.snippet: Tracking down sharing services that are free, quick and technologically foolproof — no matter how old you are.
articles.abstract: Tracking down sharing services that are free, quick and technologically foolproof — no matter how old you are.
articles.lead_paragraph: RECEPTIVENESS to new technologies often seems related to age. For example, more 13-year-olds than 63-year-olds understand phrases like “Waz ^?” and “N2MH.” (In case you’re over 13, those expressions are cellphonese for, “What’s up?” and “Not too much here.”)

articles.headline: 2 Sides Meet Face to Face on Dow Jones
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch made clear that he would not accept a sale proposal that would keep The Wall Street Journal out of his editorial control.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch made clear that he would not accept a sale proposal that would keep The Wall Street Journal out of his editorial control.
articles.lead_paragraph: In their first face-to-face meeting, the family that controls Dow Jones & Company yesterday told Rupert Murdoch, a suitor some family members mistrust deeply, that it would sell him the company only if its jewel, The Wall Street Journal, could be shielded from editorial interference from him.

articles.headline: When Fakery Turns Fatal
articles.snippet: Food scares are the latest indications that producing fake goods is still woven into the fabric of China’s economy.
articles.abstract: Food scares are the latest indications that producing fake goods is still woven into the fabric of China’s economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WUDI, China — They might be called China’s renegade businessmen, small entrepreneurs who are experts at counterfeiting and willing to go to extraordinary lengths to make a profit. But just how far out of the Chinese mainstream are they?

articles.headline: Military Judges Dismiss Charges for 2 Detainees
articles.snippet: The rulings, the latest legal setbacks for the government’s effort to bring war crimes charges against detainees, could stall the military’s prosecutions at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
articles.abstract: The rulings, the latest legal setbacks for the government’s effort to bring war crimes charges against detainees, could stall the military’s prosecutions at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba, June 4 — The government’s new system for trying Guantánamo detainees was thrown into turmoil Monday, when military judges in separate decisions dismissed war crimes charges against two of the detainees.

articles.headline: Competing as Software Goes to Web
articles.snippet: In the battle between Apple and Microsoft, two men are in charge of competing efforts to ensure that the PC’s basic software stays relevant in a Web-centered world.
articles.abstract: In the battle between Apple and Microsoft, two men are in charge of competing efforts to ensure that the PC’s basic software stays relevant in a Web-centered world.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 — Can two bitter rivals save the desktop operating system?

articles.headline: That Warm Sound of Old in a Cold, Compressed World
articles.snippet: Software and hardware are available that try to sweeten digital sound by putting back what compression has taken out.
articles.abstract: Software and hardware are available that try to sweeten digital sound by putting back what compression has taken out.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABOUT 20 years ago, Roger Adler, a guitarist and keyboard player in the Chicago area, gladly gave up his antiquated record player, his collection of 2,000 albums and the ritualistic care that the vinyl records required. For years, he enjoyed the convenience of CDs and then MP3s.

articles.headline: Cheated of Future, Iraqi Graduates Want to Flee
articles.snippet: Four years after starting college, Iraq’s college graduates are ending their studies shattered and eager to leave.
articles.abstract: Four years after starting college, Iraq’s college graduates are ending their studies shattered and eager to leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, June 4 — They started college just before or after the American invasion with dreams of new friends and parties, brilliant teachers and advanced degrees that would lead to stellar jobs, marriage and children. Success seemed well within their grasp.
